item.title: 1_A
item.description: Intro in this assignment, I had to code a form in C# and VB.NET that firstly by pressing a button would show a text, secondly another button would animate a little ball in a rectangle. Live Demo here, you can see my program in action C# code: using System; using System.Collections.Generic; using System.ComponentModel; using System.Data; using System.Drawing; using System.Drawing.Drawing2D; using System.Linq; using System.Text; using System.Threading.Tasks; using System.Windows.Forms; namespace _1_R { public partial class Form1 : System.
item.content:
Intro

in this assignment, I had to code a form in C# and VB.NET that firstly by pressing a button would show a text, secondly another button would animate a little ball in a rectangle.

Live Demo

here, you can see my program in action

C# code:

using System;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.ComponentModel;
using System.Data;
using System.Drawing;
using System.Drawing.Drawing2D;
using System.Linq;
using System.Text;
using System.Threading.Tasks;
using System.Windows.Forms;

namespace _1_R
{
    public partial class Form1 : System.Windows.Forms.Form
    {
        // Ball params
        private const int ballWidth = 50;
        private const int ballHeight = 50;
        private int ballX, ballY;   // Position.
        private int ballVx, ballVy; // Velocity.

        public Form1()
        {
            InitializeComponent();
            Random rnd = new Random();
            ballVx = rnd.Next(1, 4);
            ballVy = rnd.Next(1, 4);
            ballX = rnd.Next(0, panel1.Width - ballWidth);
            ballY = rnd.Next(0, panel1.Height - ballHeight);

            // Use double buffering to reduce flicker.
            this.SetStyle(
                ControlStyles.AllPaintingInWmPaint |
                ControlStyles.UserPaint |
                ControlStyles.DoubleBuffer,
                true);
            this.UpdateStyles();
        }

        private void button1_Click(object sender, EventArgs e)
        {
            richTextBox1.Text = "Hello World!";
        }

        private void button2_Click(object sender, EventArgs e)
        {

            timer1.Enabled = true;
            button3.Enabled = true;
        }

        private void button3_Click(object sender, EventArgs e)
        {
            timer1.Enabled = false;
        }

        private void tmrMoveBall_Tick(object sender, EventArgs e)
        {
            ballX += ballVx;
            if (ballX < 0)
            {
                ballVx = -ballVx;
            }
            else if (ballX + ballWidth > panel1.Width)
            {
                ballVx = -ballVx;
            }

            ballY += ballVy;
            if (ballY < 0)
            {
                ballVy = -ballVy;
            }
            else if (ballY + ballHeight > panel1.Height)
            {
                ballVy = -ballVy;
            }

            Refresh();
   
        }

        private void panel1_Paint(object sender, PaintEventArgs e)
        {
            
            e.Graphics.SmoothingMode = SmoothingMode.AntiAlias;
            e.Graphics.Clear(BackColor);
            e.Graphics.FillEllipse(Brushes.Blue, ballX, ballY,
                ballWidth, ballHeight);
            e.Graphics.DrawEllipse(Pens.Black, ballX, ballY,
                ballWidth, ballHeight);
            
        }  
    }
}

VB.NET code:

Imports System
Imports System.Drawing.Drawing2D
Imports System.Windows.Forms

Namespace _1_R
    Public Partial Class Form1
        Inherits System.Windows.Forms.Form

        ' Ball params
        Private Const ballWidth As Integer = 50
        Private Const ballHeight As Integer = 50
        Private ballX, ballY As Integer   ' Position.
        Private ballVx, ballVy As Integer ' Velocity.
        Public Sub New()
            InitializeComponent()
            Dim rnd As Random = New Random()
            ballVx = rnd.Next(1, 4)
            ballVy = rnd.Next(1, 4)
            ballX = rnd.[Next](0, panel1.Width - ballWidth)
            ballY = rnd.[Next](0, panel1.Height - ballHeight)

            ' Use double buffering to reduce flicker.
            Me.SetStyle(ControlStyles.AllPaintingInWmPaint Or ControlStyles.UserPaint Or ControlStyles.DoubleBuffer, True)
            Me.UpdateStyles()
        End Sub

        Private Sub button1_Click(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As EventArgs)
            richTextBox1.Text = "Hello World!"
        End Sub

        Private Sub button2_Click(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As EventArgs)
            timer1.Enabled = True
            button3.Enabled = True
        End Sub

        Private Sub button3_Click(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As EventArgs)
            timer1.Enabled = False
        End Sub

        Private Sub tmrMoveBall_Tick(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As EventArgs)
            ballX += ballVx

            If ballX < 0 Then
                ballVx = -ballVx
            ElseIf ballX + ballWidth > panel1.Width Then
                ballVx = -ballVx
            End If

            ballY += ballVy

            If ballY < 0 Then
                ballVy = -ballVy
            ElseIf ballY + ballHeight > panel1.Height Then
                ballVy = -ballVy
            End If

            Refresh()
        End Sub

        Private Sub panel1_Paint(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As PaintEventArgs)
            e.Graphics.SmoothingMode = SmoothingMode.AntiAlias
            e.Graphics.Clear(BackColor)
            e.Graphics.FillEllipse(Brushes.Blue, ballX, ballY, ballWidth, ballHeight)
            e.Graphics.DrawEllipse(Pens.Black, ballX, ballY, ballWidth, ballHeight)
        End Sub
    End Class
End Namespace

item.title: 1_R : LET'S TALK ABOUT STATISTICS
item.description: What is statistics? üìä “If a 30 year old man has his head in an oven and his feet in ice, a statistician would say that on average he feels fine.” There are tons of data out there and all those numbers alone don’t make much sense, this is where the statistics comes in, in statistics we carry out analysis, interpretation, organization and presentation of this data, so informed decision can be made.
item.content:
What is statistics? üìä

“If a 30 year old man has his head in an oven and his feet in ice, a statistician would say that on average he feels fine.”

There are tons of data out there and all those numbers alone don’t make much sense, this is where the statistics comes in, in statistics we carry out analysis, interpretation, organization and presentation of this data, so informed decision can be made. A trivial example that we can observe every day are the weather forecasts, to make this forecasts statisticians create computer models based on previous weather reports. But statistics is literally everywhere, here’s an example of some of the sectors that use it:

  • Pharmaceutical Industry
  • Food Industry
  • Plants
  • Designer Brands
  • Computers
  • Insurance
  • Finance
  • Medicine

In addition, in this historical moment we all know unfortunately that there’s a pandemic of Covid-19 in progress, even here the statistics play a key role, as you can make estimates of how many contagions there may be in the future, given the current contagions. Take Covid vaccines also as an example, did you know that pharmaceutical companies like Pfizer employ many statisticians? Here they analyze the results conducted in preclinical research and clinical trials, to help then develop a vaccine that is safe and effective.

Is statistics a science, a branch of mathematics or both? ü§î

We can summarize the above with a quote from American Statistical Association:

“Statistics is the science of learning from data, and of measuring, controlling and communicating uncertainty.”

also, John Turkey (author of Exploratory Dat Analysis) said:

‚ÄúStatistics is a science, not a branch of mathematics, but it uses mathematical models as essential tools.‚Äù

What‚Äôs the difference?

The primary difference between the two is uncertainty.

Consider two problems:

  • How far is it to work in miles?
  • How far is it to work in minutes?

The first problem is a math problem because, assuming you take the same route, the answer is fixed. The second problem is a statistical problem because you will not always get the same answer due to weather or traffic conditions, how many lights you get stuck at etc., there is a level of uncertainty.

Now in order to understand statistics you do need to know probability which is a branch of mathematics (The study of finite measures that a normalized to 1). But probability is not statistics anymore than algebra is physics.

Also, what defines a scientific field?

Every field of scientific inquiry is defined by three things:

  • What it studies: Statistics is the study of uncertainty. More specifically, it is the science of probability.

  • Why it studies the What: The outcomes of any and every natural process vary in random, yet understandable, ways (i.e. Natural Variation). Statistics examines and specifies these patterns of randomness. By understanding natural variation, we are able to identify occurrences of unnatural variation and seek their underlying cause.

  • How it studies the What: Like many sciences, mathematics is the formal language of statistics. However, it is not its only tool. Statistics also uses computers for both simulation and analysis.

So, many people view statistics as a branch of mathematics, in many ways this is true, because its origins lie within mathematics. However, it have evolved past that and is its own independent field of inquiry.

Credits

I want to thank and mention some resources that I found particularly helpful in the writing of this post:

  • Aveea : What is Statistics? (and what can you do with it)

  • Kenneth Ganning (Ph.D Statistics), Thom Flottemesch (Ph.D Statistics) : What is statistics a science of?

item.title: MY FIRST POST
item.description: Hello there, this is my first blog post. I don’t have much to say about this, but I invite you to stay tuned because in the coming days will come out many articles. Also, there will be two categories of post here: Researches about theory (R) Applications / Practice (A) So, keep in mind which one of the two letters the post contains, because it is to specify at a glance its type.
item.content:
Hello there, this is my first blog post. I don’t have much to say about this, but I invite you to stay tuned because in the coming days will come out many articles.

Also, there will be two categories of post here:

  • Researches about theory (R)
  • Applications / Practice (A)

So, keep in mind which one of the two letters the post contains, because it is to specify at a glance its type.

Example:

  • 1_R its a possible title of a post about Research
  • 1_A its a possible title of a post about Applications / Practice
